Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Evolution and Ecology of Brooding Anemones

POR.DRECONTENT:
Most species of sea anemone release larval offspring that, after being carried away by currents, will settle and develop in a new location.  In some species, however, offspring are held by the adult until a certain developmental stage has been reached. It is thought that these offspring are being protected until they reach a sufficient size to live independently. My research focuses on the evolution and significance of this behavior, called brooding, in sea anemones. Brooding is a widespread behavior among marine animal groups, but has only been studied in-depth in a few of them. The results of these studies are used to form general hypotheses about brooding, but they may not be applicable to all brooding organisms. Investigating this behavior in many different groups is important because it can reveal which findings are broadly true and which are specific to the system in which they were studied.

The research funded by this grant was carried out with the assistance of Dr. Wada in Hakodate, Japan.   He has previously advised students studying brooding sea anemones, and is located near many sites where those animals can be easily collected. The outcome of the work funded by this grant is that I was able to make collections of brooding and non-brooding anemones from seven sites widely distributed on the Island of Hokkiado. Collections made during this trip are being used to answer several different questions. They are being used to study the effect of brooding on genetic diversity at the scale of whole populations. They will be compared with similar brooding individuals from the Aleutian Islands and the west coast of North America in order to determine how many species brood in the North pacific, and the extent of their ranges. These collections are also being used in an evolutionary study which aims to determine whether all brooding sea anemone species are closely related, or if the behavior has arisen multiple times in different lineages. Finally, since individuals in this species have both male and female gonads, a genetic comparison of adults with their offspring is being used to determine whether adults fertilize themselves or each other to produce their young.

Because of the many ways in which brooding is carried out, my research can continue to investigate this phenomenon beyond my career as a graduate student. Why is brooding more common in polar regions?  What are the tradeoffs involved with brooding rather than broadcasting young, or internal brooding rather than external brooding? How do the protective structures found in some externally brooding species compare with one another? These are all promising questions that have yet to be investigated in this group of animals, and which can provide a counter-point to similar studies focusing on other animal groups.
